structures.description: Used to compare two things, showing how one thing has more of a quality than another.
forms: Adjectives ending in -y: change -y to -i and add -er (happy → happier)
Long adjectives: use 'more' before the adjective (beautiful → more beautiful)
examples: She is taller than her brother.
This exercise is more difficult than the last one.

exercises.question: My brother is ___ than me.
exercises.explanation: For short adjectives like 'tall', we add '-er' to form the comparative.

exercises.question: This book is ___ than the one I read last week.
exercises.explanation: For longer adjectives like 'interesting', we use 'more' before the adjective.

exercises.question: Learning English is ___ than learning Spanish for me.
exercises.explanation: For adjectives ending in -y, we change -y to -i and add -er.

exercises.question: My car is ___ than yours.
exercises.explanation: For short adjectives ending in consonant-vowel-consonant, we double the final consonant and add -er.

exercises.question: The weather today is ___ than yesterday.
exercises.explanation: Some adjectives have irregular comparative forms. The comparative of 'bad' is 'worse'.

structures.description: Used to compare more than two things, showing which has the most of a quality.
forms: Adjectives ending in -y: change -y to -i and add -est (happy → happiest)
Long adjectives: use 'most' before the adjective (beautiful → most beautiful)
examples: She is the tallest in her family.
This is the most exciting book I've ever read.

exercises.question: This is ___ building in our city.
exercises.explanation: For superlatives, we use 'the' + short adjective + -est.

exercises.question: That was ___ day of my life.
exercises.explanation: For adjectives ending in -y, we change -y to -i and add -est, and use 'the' before.

exercises.question: This restaurant serves ___ food in town.
exercises.explanation: For longer adjectives, we use 'the most' before the adjective.

exercises.question: Mount Everest is ___ mountain in the world.
exercises.explanation: For superlatives, we use 'the' + short adjective + -est.

exercises.question: That was ___ experience I've ever had.
exercises.explanation: Some adjectives have irregular superlative forms. The superlative of 'bad' is 'worst'.

structures.description: Used to express duty, necessity, advice, or prohibition.
forms: Don't have to/needn't: lack of obligation
examples: You must finish your homework.
You shouldn't eat so much sugar.

exercises.question: You ___ wear a seatbelt when driving. It's the law.
exercises.explanation: We use 'must' for strong obligation, especially for laws and rules.

exercises.question: You ___ be so mean to your brother.
exercises.explanation: We use 'shouldn't' for advice against doing something.

exercises.question: You ___ go to the dentist if your tooth hurts.
exercises.explanation: We use 'should' to give advice or recommendations.

exercises.question: You ___ smoke in the hospital. It's not allowed.
exercises.explanation: We use 'mustn't' for prohibition - when something is not allowed.

exercises.question: You ___ buy tickets in advance. You can get them at the door.
exercises.explanation: We use 'don't have to' to express lack of obligation - something is not necessary.

structures.description: Used for possible situations in the future and their likely results.
examples: If it rains, I will stay at home.
If you finish your homework, you can go to the party.

exercises.question: If he ___ (study) hard, he will pass the exam.
exercises.explanation: In first conditional, we use present simple in the if-clause.

exercises.question: If it ___ (rain) tomorrow, we ___ (cancel) the picnic.
exercises.explanation: In first conditional, we use present simple in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

exercises.question: If you ___ (not/finish) your homework, you can't go out.
exercises.explanation: In first conditional, we use present simple negative in the if-clause.

exercises.question: ___ you help me if I ___ (ask) you?
exercises.explanation: In first conditional questions, we use will in the main clause and present simple in the if-clause.

exercises.question: If she ___ (come) to the party, I ___ (be) very happy.
exercises.explanation: In first conditional, we use present simple in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

structures.description: Used for hypothetical or unlikely situations in the present or future and their potential results.
examples: If I had more money, I would buy a new car.
If she came to the party, I would be happy.

exercises.question: If I ___ (win) the lottery, I would travel the world.
exercises.explanation: In second conditional, we use past simple in the if-clause for hypothetical situations.

exercises.question: If he ___ (have) more time, he ___ (learn) French.
exercises.explanation: In second conditional, we use past simple in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

exercises.question: What ___ you ___ (do) if you ___ (be) in my position?
exercises.explanation: In second conditional questions, we use would in the main clause and past simple in the if-clause.

exercises.question: If I ___ (be) you, I ___ (not/worry) about it.
exercises.explanation: In second conditional with 'be', we typically use 'were' for all persons in the if-clause.

exercises.question: She ___ (call) you if she ___ (need) help.
exercises.explanation: In second conditional, we use past simple in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

structures.description: Distinguishing between these tenses for talking about the past.
forms: Present Perfect: have/has + past participle (for experiences or actions with present relevance)
Past Simple: past form of verb (for completed actions in the past with a specific time)
examples: I have visited Paris (present perfect - life experience).
I visited Paris last year (past simple - specific time in the past).

exercises.question: I ___ (see) this movie three times.
exercises.explanation: We use present perfect for experiences without specifying exactly when they happened.

exercises.question: She ___ (go) to the store yesterday.
exercises.explanation: We use past simple for completed actions at a specific time in the past ('yesterday').

exercises.question: ___ you ever ___ (try) sushi?
exercises.explanation: We use present perfect with 'ever' to ask about life experiences.

exercises.question: I ___ (live) in London for five years when I was a child.
exercises.explanation: We use past simple for completed periods in the past (finished living in London).

exercises.question: She ___ (not/finish) her homework yet.
exercises.explanation: We use present perfect with 'yet' for actions that should happen but haven't happened so far.

structures.description: Used to report what someone else said without quoting them directly.
forms: Tense changes: present → past, past → past perfect, etc.
Pronoun changes: I → he/she, you → I/he/she, etc.
Time and place changes: now → then, here → there, etc.
examples: Direct: 'I am happy.' Reported: She said she was happy.
Direct: 'I will call you.' Reported: He said he would call me.

exercises.question: He said: 'I am studying English.' → He said (that) he ___ English.
exercises.explanation: In reported speech, present continuous (am studying) changes to past continuous (was studying).

exercises.question: She said: 'I will help you tomorrow.' → She said (that) she ___ me the next day.
exercises.explanation: In reported speech, 'will' changes to 'would' and 'tomorrow' changes to 'the next day'.

exercises.question: They said: 'We have finished the project.' → They said (that) they ___ the project.
exercises.explanation: In reported speech, present perfect (have finished) changes to past perfect (had finished).

exercises.question: Tom said: 'I can swim.' → Tom said (that) he ___ swim.
exercises.explanation: In reported speech, 'can' changes to 'could'.

exercises.question: She asked: 'Do you like coffee?' → She asked (me) if I ___ coffee.
exercises.explanation: In reported questions, present simple (do like) changes to past simple (liked).

structures.description: Used when the focus is on the action rather than who performs it.
forms: Subject + be (in appropriate tense) + past participle
examples: Active: They build houses. Passive: Houses are built.
Active: Someone stole my car. Passive: My car was stolen.

exercises.question: Active: They grow rice here. → Passive: Rice ___ here.
exercises.explanation: For present simple passive, use 'is/are' + past participle.

exercises.question: Active: Someone stole my bike yesterday. → Passive: My bike ___ yesterday.
exercises.explanation: For past simple passive, use 'was/were' + past participle.

exercises.question: Active: They are repairing the road. → Passive: The road ___.
exercises.explanation: For present continuous passive, use 'is/are being' + past participle.

exercises.question: Active: They have built a new bridge. → Passive: A new bridge ___.
exercises.explanation: For present perfect passive, use 'has/have been' + past participle.

exercises.question: Active: They will publish the book next month. → Passive: The book ___ next month.
exercises.explanation: For future simple passive, use 'will be' + past participle.

structures.description: Used to give additional information about a noun.
examples: The woman who lives next door is a doctor.
The book that I'm reading is interesting.

exercises.question: The man ___ lives next door is very friendly.
exercises.explanation: Use 'who' for people as the subject of the relative clause.

exercises.question: The book ___ I bought yesterday is very interesting.
exercises.explanation: Use 'which' for things as the object of the relative clause (or 'that').

exercises.question: The woman ___ car was stolen called the police.
exercises.explanation: Use 'whose' to show possession in relative clauses.

exercises.question: This is the house ___ I grew up in.
exercises.explanation: Use 'where' for places in relative clauses (or 'which/that...in').

exercises.question: The people ___ we met at the party were very nice.
exercises.explanation: Use 'who' for people as the object of the relative clause (or 'that').

structures.description: Used to talk about past habits or states that no longer exist.
forms: Negative: Subject + didn't use to + infinitive
Question: Did + subject + use to + infinitive
examples: I used to play tennis when I was younger.
She didn't use to like coffee, but now she loves it.

exercises.question: I ___ play football every weekend, but now I don't have time.
exercises.explanation: Use 'used to + infinitive' for past habits that no longer happen.

exercises.question: She ___ like vegetables when she was a child.
exercises.explanation: For negative statements about past habits, use 'didn't use to + infinitive'.

exercises.question: ___ you ___ live in London before moving here?
exercises.explanation: For questions about past habits, use 'Did + subject + use to + infinitive'.

exercises.question: There ___ be a cinema here, but it closed last year.
exercises.explanation: Use 'used to + infinitive' for past states that no longer exist.

exercises.question: I ___ drink coffee, but now I drink it every morning.
exercises.explanation: For negative statements about past habits, use 'didn't use to + infinitive'.

structures.description: Different verb patterns that use gerunds (-ing form) or infinitives (to + verb).
forms: Verb + object + infinitive (ask someone to help)
examples: I enjoy swimming in the sea.
She wants to learn Spanish.

exercises.question: I enjoy ___ (read) books in my free time.
exercises.explanation: After 'enjoy', we use a gerund (verb + -ing).

exercises.question: She decided ___ (study) medicine at university.
exercises.explanation: After 'decide', we use an infinitive (to + verb).

exercises.question: They suggested ___ (go) to the beach.
exercises.explanation: After 'suggest', we use a gerund (verb + -ing).

exercises.question: Would you like ___ (come) to dinner tonight?
exercises.explanation: After 'would like', we use an infinitive (to + verb).

exercises.question: I can't stand ___ (wait) in long lines.
exercises.explanation: After 'can't stand', we use a gerund (verb + -ing).
